verses.text: As for you, take up a lamentation for the princes of Israel,
verses.comment: The Lord commands Ezekiel to compose a lament, a song of mourning, for Israel’s rulers. This expresses both judgment and compassion for the lost leaders. Such laments foreshadow the weeping over Jerusalem (see Luke 19:41) and reflect the seriousness with which God's people are called to pray for their leaders.

verses.text: and say: What was your mother? A lioness! Among lions she lay down; in the midst of young lions she raised her cubs.
verses.comment: The 'mother' is a metaphor for Israel (or the royal house of David), portrayed in strength and dignity. Lion imagery often signifies royalty in scripture (see Gen. 49:9), and the young lions are her sons, the kings.

verses.text: She brought up one of her cubs; he became a young lion, and he learned to catch prey; he devoured people.
verses.comment: This is commonly interpreted as Jehoahaz, son of Josiah, who became king but was quickly removed. The phrase 'devoured people' refers to the king's power and possible injustice, a warning on the abuse of authority.

verses.text: The nations also heard about him; he was caught in their pit, and they brought him with hooks to the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: Jehoahaz was taken captive by Pharaoh Neco and brought to Egypt (see 2 Kings 23:33-34), demonstrating the vulnerability of Israel’s kings when they turn from faithfulness. The image of 'hooks' recalls defeat and humiliation.

verses.text: When she saw that she waited and her hope was lost, she took another of her cubs and made him a young lion.
verses.comment: The mother (Israel) loses hope with the fall of Jehoahaz and raises up another son, usually identified as Jehoiachin or possibly Jehoiakim. The cyclical effort to restore leadership points to the deeper need for a true, just King.

verses.text: He walked among the lions; he became a young lion and learned to catch prey; he devoured people.
verses.comment: Another king follows in the pattern of power and predation, repeating the failures of his predecessor. The desire for independence is contrasted with the curse of exile.

verses.text: He broke down their strongholds and devastated their cities. The land and its fullness were appalled at the sound of his roaring.
verses.comment: The effect of the king’s reign brings ruin, not blessing, as his 'roaring' creates fear and destruction. This can point to the consequences leaders face when their rule lacks true justice and godliness.

verses.text: Then the nations set against him from the surrounding provinces, and they spread their net over him; he was caught in their pit.
verses.comment: Jehoiachin is besieged and exiled by Babylon (see 2 Kings 24:10-16). This fulfills the prophetic warning that worldly alliances without faith in God bring disaster.

verses.text: With hooks they put him in a cage and brought him to the king of Babylon; they brought him into strongholds, so that his voice would no longer be heard on the mountains of Israel.
verses.comment: Jehoiachin’s exile silenced the royal line’s authority, a dramatic image for the end of the Davidic monarchy in Jerusalem. Yet such events set the stage for a promised righteous King who will fulfill all hopes, pointing spiritually to the coming Messiah.

verses.text: Your mother was like a vine in your vineyard, planted by the waters; she was fruitful and full of branches because of abundant water.
verses.comment: The metaphor shifts from lioness to vine. Israel is described in language of fertility and blessing, consistent with the biblical image of God's people as a fruitful vine (Ps. 80, Isa. 5). Water symbolizes grace and God’s sustaining presence.

verses.text: She had strong branches, suitable for scepters of rulers; her height was exalted above the thick branches, and she was seen in her height with the mass of her branches.
verses.comment: The strong branches symbolize Davidic kings (see Ps. 89:24-27)—fit for rule, prominent, and lifted up. This imagery underlines Israel’s intended royal destiny and foreshadows messianic fulfillment in Christ, the true King.

verses.text: But she was plucked up in fury, cast down to the ground; the east wind dried up her fruit. Her strong branches were broken off and withered. Fire consumed them.
verses.comment: The vine is uprooted—the royal line suffers and is exiled. The 'east wind' (Babylonian invasion) and the fire (judgment) illustrate the discipline that happens when God's people neglect their vocation. Yet, the pruning suggests hope for restoration.

verses.text: Now she is planted in the wilderness, in a dry and thirsty land.
verses.comment: Exile is likened to being set in a desert—a land without life and blessing. This points to spiritual desolation apart from the Lord, which is healed only by returning to him and being restored to the promises of old.

verses.text: Fire has gone out from her branch; it has consumed her shoots, so that there is no strong branch, no scepter for ruling. This is a lamentation, and it has become a lamentation.
verses.comment: The end of the kingly line is mourned; 'no scepter for ruling' anticipates the need for a new Shepherd-King. This lament implies longing for the promised everlasting covenant, eventually fulfilled in Jesus, the Messiah, who reigns eternally (see Luke 1:32-33).
